title: High body mass index and cancer risk—a Mendelian randomisation study
author: Benn
author_address: Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Gentofte Hospital, Copenhagen University Hospital, Kildega ̊rdsvej 28, 2900 Gentofte, Denmark
hypothesis: Effect of body mass index on cancer
rationale: High body mass index (BMI) has been associ- ated with increased risk of some cancer. Whether these reflect causal associations is unknown. We examined this issue.
power_calculation_how: Power to exclude a causal risk of cancer (odds ratio) at a two-sided a of 0.05 and b of 80 % was calculated using an online power calculation tool (https://sb452.shi nyapps.io/power/) for instrumental variable analysis in Mendelian Randomization studies with binary outcomes
limitations_pleiotropy: To minimize influence from pleiotropy, we carefully selected genetic instruments and used genetic variants located in five different genes combined in an allele score for body mass index, making it unlikely that the genetic variants in the allele score have the same pleiotropic effects
limitations_statistical_power: Lack of power for rare cancer

title: Genetically Predicted Body Mass Index and Breast Cancer Risk: Mendelian Randomization Analyses of Data from 145,000 Women of European Descent
author: Guo
author_address: Division of Epidemiology, Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, Nashville, Tennessee, United States of America
hypothesis: Effect of BMI on breast cancer
rationale: Observational epidemiological studies have shown that high body mass index (BMI) is associated with a reduced risk of breast cancer in premenopausal women but an increased risk in postmenopausal women. It is unclear whether this association is mediated through shared genetic or environmental factors.
outcome_definition: Defined in Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC)
outcome_n_difference_reason: Results table quotes total N not split by case/control
exposure_n_difference_reason: One-sample where they got exposure SNPs from external GWAS
exposure_independence: Selected independent SNPs, defined as r2 < 0.1
n_SNP_difference_reason: SNPs from Locke et al (77) were combined with SNPs associated with variation in BMI identified from the NHGRI-EBI Catalog of Published Genome-Wide Association Studies in August 2015
MR_sensitivity_method_results: In addition to pooled analysis also conducted meta-analysis, we estimated the risk of breast cancer associated with BMI-GS in each of the BCAC studies
replication_subsetting: Used summary statistics from the Discovery, Biology, and Risk of Inherited Variants in Breast Cancer (DRIVE) Project to look at BMI and breast cancer risk
limitations_overall: Our study has certain limitations. To date, GWAS-identified SNPs represent a small, but statistically significant, portion of the explained variance of observed BMI—approximately 2.7%
limitations_pleiotropy: some of the BMI-associated SNPs may be related to other traits. However, we were unable to evaluate these hypotheses in our study.
limitations_statistical_power: Using data from approximately 146,000 women involved in two large consortia, we provide strong evidence of an inverse association between genetically predicted BMI and breast cancer risk for both premenopausal and postmenopausal women
